comments.commentBody: The kid was not hired by the FAA to do the work. No one who had not gone through the process to be in the position of controlling air traffic should be doing that. Not just a kid, the controller could not bring his cousin, his mom, his best friend, his fiance to do any of that. They were never hired to do the job and were simply 'not qualified'. If the kid wants to play landing and takeoff he can do it at home, but not in a 'real-life' situation where the lives of hundreds of innocent people could be at risk.
Well, this seemed like a classic Thursday in difficulty to me, and really fun to boot when the six starred fills finally revealed what they all had in common. And so good night.

Lighten up, everyone. Let's assume the controller was watching and doing his job and then was ready to clear the plane for takeoff. What harm in having his kid say those words? Come ON!!! Have we lost all sense of perspective? Until it can be shown that that controller actually put anyone in danger, let's not form a hanging posse just yet. Sounds to me like he was being a great dad, and giving his kids a taste of his job's realities. Has everyone suddenly become Scrooge?

Sorry, but trying to leverage a few World Series tickets is not an indictable offense.  The real question is, not whether David Paterson should resign, but rather who is trying to destroy him, and why.

People! People! Get a hold of your hysterical selves! There isn't some conspiracy to "get the black man out of power." The governor was asked under oath if he'd solicited free seats from the Yankees and he flat out lied about it because he wanted to remain in power. He didn't want his constituents to know that he's just another corrupt politician with his hand out expecting favors.

He could have just fessed up when he got caught, paid the civil fine, and moved on. But his ego and thirst for power got the better of him. He wanted to run for governor and he didn't want the public to know that he was just another slimy politician. I don't know about the rest of you apathetic voters sans integrity, but I don't want people seeking government office in order to get favors from corporations like the Yankees.

What has happened to our nation that so many of YOU have gotten to the point that you just don't care that your elected officials are taking favors from people and companies doing business with our state? Everyone just puts up with corruption with a wink and a nod and then wonders why we have so many corrupt politicians. Go figure!

It's time to resign, governor, and let the next person see if he or she can avoid the temptation to grease his or her palm. It's like a game of musical chairs...

And for those of you complaining about the NY Times, what did you want them to do, not report the results of the ethics investigation? It's all over every paper in the city and state and every news program. Why are you singling out the NY Times for doing its job? Is the NY times supposed to pretend they don't know?

I believe Andre (#4 18) means the office should be vacant not vacated.  As for Gov. Paterson, what he is accused of, while not the biggest crime, may just be the tip of the iceberg. Is that what he wants to do with his time is go see a baseball game. He lied about when the check was written (as pointed out the face value is not the real value) and that he was invited by the Yankees (who had a vested interest in doing a favor in return for some favorable bond deal). He lies and cheats and should not be governor. Why defend him and why believe in him? He is a CROOK. The litmus test is what if he were a Republican? How long would he last. Why doesn't NY get an honest person in that office? Surely there must be someone who can do the job. Dare say this mess should be considered Ticketgate, for those who remember the Watergate Hotel in the 1970s and Richard Nixon. Nixon did a lot less than Spitzer or Paterson. He had no prior knowledge of what his operatives were doing and did a coverup. Isn't that what Paterson has done with his staff person? There is remarkable similarities but NYers are so naive if they think Paterson is any different.

This whole story about Johnson's phone call to the Yankees, Paterson's shuck and jive lie about Levine, and the check... then the dumb mis-dating of the check by Johnson.... Then Johnson roughs up the girlfriend and Paterson sics the State Police, himself, and his own staff on her to "make it go away."

They're like two small-change, petty-con pikers who accidentally fell into the big leagues, got caught up short, and landed in at least the soup, if not the clink.

But it's crazy how all these guys go ga ga over BALL GAMES!! Giuliani and Bloomberg too. Selling their city and state for a lousy ball game (oh, and a few diamond club rings and maybe a piece of a stadium).

What a pathetic joke!!! How cheaply these clowns can be bought off. The great state of New York!!!
Doesn't Andrew Cuomo's mother have connections to ORGANIZED CRIME? That's what this witchunt against the Governor is really about!
NYT this is an over-kill.

I can understand people wanting the Governor to resign if he indeed played a part in silencing a victim of physical abuse.Yes kick him out but if he looses his job because of a few baseball tickets, then what about all the hot shot financiers on wall street who bankrupt thousands of people never mind Greece ! Lets go after the real criminals.

Before Patterson became Governor nobody cared or noticed that he was an Albany hack and chronic liar. The truth does not dwell within Governor Patterson; it will only get worse.   If Patterson couldn't get his act together after being thrust into unaccustomed prominence he never will.

So this is how you are treated if you don't do what Pres. Obama wants.  He wouldn't step down so they are going to throw him to the curb.  I'm not a Gov. Patterson fan, however this is the United States and I am ashamed of the witch hunt.  Shame on the Democratic party.

One Paper. Two Governors. Two Years.
The New York Times Cleans the House

Congratulations on another Pulitzer to Confessore, Peters and everyone who worked on this fantastic series of investigation, reporting, writing and editing.

Bravo!
Seems like a witch hunt if ever I have seen one. Come on, seriously? Receiving World series tickets is unethical? Politics is such a farcical game and a complete waste of time.

Yankee tickets?  Are you serious?  I guess it's only "America's Pastime" and an historically acceptable thing to attend for a high profile NY politico, if it's a white New York City Mayor.  I guess the Times sees the Journal's new city section as a threat, since you lamely closed yours, and now you feel like you have to act like the Post, or FOX news.  So sad.  Never thought I'd see the day when I actually had NOTHING of substance, newspaper-wise, to be loyal to in New York City.  p.s.  I'm white, and union.

It was only recently that an ATC in NJ/NYC who was engaged in a personal phone conversation that led to the deaths of 9 people when a small aircraft struck a tourist helicopter over the Hudson River. The tower should be a sterile environment focused on the task at hand, directing air traffic. An ATC has no business allowing a child to direct aircraft, no matter how cute he may think it is. The catastrophic consequences of a lapse of attention are well documented in aviation and after the Teterboro incident you would have thought that the FAA would have instituted stricter rules to curb any nominal distractions from jeopardizing the traveling public.

Forgive my skepticism. Forty thousand gang members are not playing penuckle. Besides, the fiscally-challenged State of California can't afford to keep housing the other 40,000 that are cramming the jails & angering judges who aren't fond of inhumane treatment of inmates.And are the LAPD playing the "stop & frisk" minorities game Bob Herbert exposed in his column last week on the NYPD's policy? That may locate a few bad guys, but it is just as likely to create more.

Perhaps it's because I too cannot forget watching in near-disbelief -- as it happened -- men beating Reginald Denny, nor can I forget the heroic Bobby Green, Titus Murphy, Terri Barnett & Lei Yuille who saved Denny from the savages who nearly took his life & left him permanently disabled. The hatred spewed on Reginald Denny cannot be far from the surface. I once heard a Los Angeles rabbi, speaking of the Holocaust, say, "Absent evil, there is no heroism." We must hope the heroism of Denny's saviors isn't required again. But it's a hope that defies experience.

Policing can do only so much. The real salvation lies is education, social stability and economic opportunity. To achieve these requires a government with an enlightened agenda. The resurgence of right-wing. race-based, "me-first" populism is the biggest threat fragile communities like South Central face. I suppose people had lots of fun watching Sarah Palin perform standup on Jay Leno not so far from the corner of Florence & Normandie. But it won't be so hilarious if Leno, Roger Ailes, et al., succeed in lifting people like Sarah Palin into positions of power. Expect to see a new breakdown of at-risk neighborhoods, more needless loss of quality of life, and loss of life itself.

The Constant Weader at www.RealityChex.com

I'd have to agree.  My wife and I have lived in LA for more than 16 years, and we have been continuously exploring the city, and so far safely.  After we've taken trips outside the country, we come back and say, I'll bet we could have a similar experience at home - so we visit Artesia (India), or Chinatown, or Little Toyko, or Westminster (Viet Nam), and so on.  And we do it doing the day and at night.  It's a pretty entertaining place.
marijuana dispensiries = less crime. fact. see Los Angeles in 2010

My girlfriend was dosed with LSD in her drink here in December 2009 - at 6pm! I DO NOT SAY THIS LIGHTLY. We went for a sunset drink and left after two margaritas. While driving back to Playa del Carmen, she started experiencing extreme intoxication, nausea, then a very very long night of hallucinating, fear and paranoia. I know the difference between drunk and tripping. This was a very difficult, very painful long night. This ruined not only our last night, but the entire Christmas vacation, and after 11 years of coming to Playa and Tulum, it's destroyed the idea of ever coming back to the area, or possibly even Mexico. The Cancunization of the entire coast is rampant.
If you need any more evidence of problems in the area: Tulum, Dec 2009, "12th Journalist Gunned Down In Mexico This Year" - http://bit.ly/ddZ6u0 - "It is said that Velazquez, as he was dying, accused allies of the Mayor of Tulum of being responsible for his death"

This was the email response from the owners after contacting them three times: "We take all customer communications seriously and have taken time to consider the matter you brought to our attention thoroughly. We discussed this matter with the appropriate authorities and our management team. All parties agreed that without any evidence, we can do nothing in response" Somehow I find it extremely unlikely they went to the Mexican Police and told them one of their waiters has been accused of drugging a customer.

As the product of a Northeast Louisiana Farmer, Baptist Minister, and Usher Board President. both my parents always extolled the virtue of this one old adage to myself and my eight siblings: "Don't merely listen to what people say?" "No, watch what they do?"

This is what Utah Sen. Orrin Hatch said:

"This use of Reconciliation to jam through this legislation-healthcare, the havoc wrought would threaten our system of checks-and-balances...!"

This is what Utah Sen. Orrin Hatch has voted for via Reconciliation:

1. Omnibus Budget "Reconciliation" Act of 1989
2. Balanced Budget Act of 1995
3. Personal Responsibility & Work Opportunity "Reconciliation" Act of 1996
4. Balanced Budget Act of 1997
5. Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997
6. Taxpayer Refund & Relief Act of 1999
7. Marriage Tax Relief "Reconciliation" Act of 2000
8. Economic Growth & Tax Relief "Reconciliation" Act of 2001
9. Jobs & Growth Tax Relief "Reconciliation" Act of 2005
10. Deficit Reduction Act of 2005
11. Tax Increase Prevention & "Reconciliation" Act of 2005
12. College Cost Reduction & Access Act of 2007

President Obama need neither heed the threats of hypocritical Republicans, nor the voices of reconciliation-opposition. For God sake, just get it done Democrats...for all of America!

The Senate is an undemocratic institution which is why South Dakota and California have two senators each. It is governed undemocratically with arcane and feudal rules and traditions such as the one that let Senator Bunning hold up the will of 99 other senators. The filibuster is another one of those measures, one that kept civil rights and even anti-lynching bills from being passed for almost a century.

Now another strange rule: the reconciliation process is being used to circumvent the stranglehold of the filibuster. Reconciliation is being implemented to allow for majority rule in this case. I can see why the Republicans are mad: they don't like the rule that lets the Democrats get around their favorite rule of the moment---though they used reconciliation to bankrupt us with the Bush tax cuts. I can see why they're mad, but their claim that it's undemocratic is completely bogus.

You know, there are just too many people complaining about Obama's "props in lab coats." Anybody remember when George Bush put on a flight suit and stood on a carrier and claimed the war in Iraq was "won." Politicians wear cowboy hats in Texas, suits in Washington and shirtsleeves at the church picnic.  Get over it.
This package is not enough to solve all the health care issues but it is a step in the right direction. Republicans are clueless.
